Oblivious Subspace Embedding

In an earlier post, we saw how the Johnson-Lindenstrauss Transform can reduce the dimensionality of a set of m points while preserving their pairwise distances. That's neat, but what if we need to preserve the pairwise distance between all (infinitely many) points in an entire subspace? This post introduces the concept of subspace embedding, which answers that question.

Published

25 August 2024

Tags: Randomized Numerical Linear Algebra

Say we have a matrix A∈Rn×dA \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times d}A∈Rn×d where n≫dn \gg dn≫d. If a linear map S∈Rk×nS \in \mathbb{R}^{k \times n}S∈Rk×n, where k≪nk \ll nk≪n, has the property that, for all x∈Rdx \in \mathbb{R}^dx∈Rd and some ϵ∈(0,1)\epsilon \in (0, 1)ϵ∈(0,1), the following holds:

(1−ϵ)∥Ax∥2≤∥SAx∥2≤(1+ϵ)∥Ax∥2, (1 - \epsilon) \lVert Ax \rVert_2 \leq \lVert SAx \rVert_2 \leq (1+\epsilon) \lVert Ax \rVert_2, (1−ϵ)∥Ax∥2​≤∥SAx∥2​≤(1+ϵ)∥Ax∥2​,

then we call SSS an ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​-subspace embedding of the column space of AAA, or simply an ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​-subspace embedding of AAA. Essentially, SSS preserves norms of the column space of AAA up to ϵ\epsilonϵ amount of error. To simplify notation, I’ll write the above expression as: ∥SAx∥2=(1±ϵ)∥Ax∥2\lVert SAx \rVert_2 = (1 \pm \epsilon) \lVert Ax \rVert_2∥SAx∥2​=(1±ϵ)∥Ax∥2​.

We can, without loss of generality, assume that AAA has orthonormal columns. That is because, if that’s not the case, we can redefine A:=UA:=UA:=U where UUU comes from the SVD of A=UΣV∗A=U\Sigma V^\astA=UΣV∗. Indeed, the sets {y  ∣  y=Ax,  x∈Rd}\{ y \;|\; y = Ax,\; x \in \mathbb{R}^d \}{y∣y=Ax,x∈Rd} and {y  ∣  y=Uz,  z∈Rρ}\{ y \;|\; y=Uz, \; z \in \mathbb{R}^\rho \}{y∣y=Uz,z∈Rρ} where ρ=rank(A)\rho=\mathop{rank}(A)ρ=rank(A) are the same.

What that means is that, we can simplify the condition to: ∥SAx∥2=(1±ϵ)∥x∥2\lVert SAx \rVert_2 = (1 \pm \epsilon) \lVert x \rVert_2∥SAx∥2​=(1±ϵ)∥x∥2​. We can also require that the above hold for unit vectors xxx due to the linearity of the maps involved. That is in turn equivalent to ∥I−A∗S∗SA∥2≤ϵ\lVert I - A^\ast S^\ast S A \lVert_2 \leq \epsilon∥I−A∗S∗SA∥2​≤ϵ where ∥⋅∥2\lVert \cdot \rVert_2∥⋅∥2​ is the operator norm of its argument. To see this:

∥SAx∥2=(1±ϵ)∥x∥2⇒∣x∗(A∗S∗SA−I)x∣≤ϵ∥x∥2⇒sup⁡∥x∥2=1∣x∗(A∗S∗SA−I)x∣≤ϵ⇒sup⁡∥x∥2=1∣x∗Σx∣≤ϵ⇒σ1(A∗S∗SA−I)≤ϵ \begin{aligned} \lVert S&A x \rVert_2 = (1 \pm \epsilon) \lVert x \rVert_2 \Rightarrow \\ & \big\lvert x^\ast \big( A^\ast S^\ast S A - I \big) x \big\rvert \leq \epsilon \lVert x \rVert_2 \Rightarrow \\ & \sup_{\lVert x \rVert_2 = 1} \big\lvert x^\ast \big( A^\ast S^\ast S A - I \big) x \big\rvert \leq \epsilon \Rightarrow \\ & \sup_{\lVert x \rVert_2 = 1} \big\lvert x^\ast \Sigma x \big\rvert \leq \epsilon \Rightarrow \\ & \sigma_1(A^\ast S^\ast S A - I) \leq \epsilon \end{aligned} ∥S​Ax∥2​=(1±ϵ)∥x∥2​⇒∣∣∣​x∗(A∗S∗SA−I)x∣∣∣​≤ϵ∥x∥2​⇒∥x∥2​=1sup​∣∣∣​x∗(A∗S∗SA−I)x∣∣∣​≤ϵ⇒∥x∥2​=1sup​∣∣∣​x∗Σx∣∣∣​≤ϵ⇒σ1​(A∗S∗SA−I)≤ϵ​

where we used the SVD (A∗S∗SA−I)=UΣV∗(A^\ast S^\ast SA - I)=U \Sigma V^\ast(A∗S∗SA−I)=UΣV∗ and the fact that UUU and VVV have orthonormal columns.

What properties should SSS have? Well, first and foremost, we want k≪nk \ll nk≪n so that SASASA has as few rows as possible. That is, we want the smallest subspace of the column space of AAA that offers a (1±ϵ)(1 \pm \epsilon)(1±ϵ)-approximation of the Euclidean norm. Additionally, we want to be able to compute SASASA rather quickly. That often means we prefer a sparser SSS.

Definition

Suppose that we have a distribution Π\PiΠ over the space of all k×nk \times nk×n linear maps, where kkk is a function of n,d,ϵ,δn, d, \epsilon, \deltan,d,ϵ,δ, with the following property: For every S∼ΠS \sim \PiS∼Π and any fixed matrix A∈Rn×dA \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times d}A∈Rn×d, with probability at least 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ, SSS is a (1±ϵ)(1 \pm \epsilon)(1±ϵ) ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​-subspace embedding of AAA. Then we call Π\PiΠ an (ϵ,δ)(\epsilon, \delta)(ϵ,δ) oblivious ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​-subspace embedding.

As a side-note, in addition to oblivious embeddings, we can design sampling-based sketching algorithms that are called Leverage Score Sampling. I’ll discuss these in a later post.

Construction

Theorem: Let S=1kR∈Rk×nS=\frac{1}{\sqrt{k}}R \in \mathbb{R}^{k \times n}S=k​1​R∈Rk×n where the entries of RRR are iid standard normal random variables. If k=Θ(ϵ−2(d+log⁡(1/δ)))k = \Theta\big(\epsilon^{-2} (d + \log(1/\delta)) \big)k=Θ(ϵ−2(d+log(1/δ))), then SSS is a (1±ϵ)(1 \pm \epsilon)(1±ϵ) ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​-subspace embedding for any matrix A∈Rn×dA \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times d}A∈Rn×d with probability at least 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ.

Proof: Notice that, we are trying to find an ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​-subspace embedding for the column space of AAA. We can also focus only on unit vectors in the column space, due to linearity. The idea behind the proof is to first lay an ϵ\epsilonϵ-net over the column space of AAA with the property that, a Johnson-Lindenstrauss Transform for the ϵ\epsilonϵ-net is a ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​-subspace embedding for the entire space. Let’s get to it.

Consider the set S={y  ∣  y=Ax,  ∥y∥2=1}\mathcal{S} = \{ y \;|\; y = Ax,\; \lVert y \rVert_2 = 1 \}S={y∣y=Ax,∥y∥2​=1} and its 1/21/21/2-net N\mathcal{N}N. We can write every y∈Sy \in Sy∈S as the series: y=∑i=0∞wiy = \sum_{i=0}^{\infty} w_iy=∑i=0∞​wi​ where wiw_iwi​ is a scaled member of N\mathcal{N}N with the property that ∥wi∥≤2−i\lVert w_i \rVert \leq 2^{-i}∥wi​∥≤2−i. To see that that’s always possible, take w0:=v0∈Nw_0 := v_0 \in \mathcal{N}w0​:=v0​∈N and write y=w0+(y−w0)y = w_0 + (y - w_0)y=w0​+(y−w0​). Clearly ∥y−w0∥2≤1/2\lVert y - w_0 \rVert_2 \leq 1/2∥y−w0​∥2​≤1/2 because w0∈Nw_0 \in \mathcal{N}w0​∈N. Now write y=w0+w1+(y−w0−w1)y = w_0 + w_1 + (y - w_0 - w_1)y=w0​+w1​+(y−w0​−w1​) where w1=∥y−w0∥2v1w_1 = \lVert y - w_0 \rVert_2 v_1w1​=∥y−w0​∥2​v1​ for some v1∈Nv_1 \in \mathcal{N}v1​∈N. Then:

∥y−w0−w1∥2=∥y−w0∥2⋅∥y−w0∥y−w0∥2−v1∥2≤∥y−w0∥22≤14, \lVert y - w_0 - w_1 \rVert_2 = \lVert y - w_0 \rVert_2 \cdot \lVert \frac{y - w_0}{\lVert y - w_0 \rVert_2} - v_1 \rVert_2 \leq \frac{\lVert y - w_0 \rVert_2}{2} \leq \frac{1}{4}, ∥y−w0​−w1​∥2​=∥y−w0​∥2​⋅∥∥y−w0​∥2​y−w0​​−v1​∥2​≤2∥y−w0​∥2​​≤41​,

as desired. We can continue to expand the residual as above and reason by induction.

Now consider a JLT for N\mathcal{N}N, SSS, so that with probability at least 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ, we have that ⟨Sv,Sv′⟩=⟨v,v′⟩±ϵ\langle Sv, Sv^\prime \rangle = \langle v, v^\prime \rangle \pm \epsilon⟨Sv,Sv′⟩=⟨v,v′⟩±ϵ for all pairs of v,v′∈Nv, v^\prime \in \mathcal{N}v,v′∈N. If we applied the same map to any y∈Sy \in \mathcal{S}y∈S, then we’d get, with probability at least 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ:

⟨Sy,Sy⟩=⟨∑Swi,∑Swi⟩=∑i⟨Swi,Swi⟩+∑i≠j⟨Swi,Swj⟩=∑i∥wi∥22+∑i≠j⟨wi,wj⟩±ϵ∑i,j∥wi∥2∥wj∥2=⟨∑wi,∑wi⟩+O(ϵ)=⟨y,y⟩±O(ϵ). \begin{aligned} \langle Sy, Sy \rangle &= \langle \sum S w_i, \sum Sw_i \rangle \\ &= \sum_i \langle Sw_i, Sw_i \rangle + \sum_{i \neq j} \langle Sw_i, Sw_j \rangle \\ &= \sum_i \lVert w_i \rVert_2^2 + \sum_{i \neq j} \langle w_i, w_j \rangle \pm \epsilon \sum_{i, j} \lVert w_i \rVert_2 \lVert w_j \rVert_2 \\ &= \langle \sum w_i, \sum w_i \rangle + \mathcal{O}(\epsilon) \\ &= \langle y, y \rangle \pm \mathcal{O}(\epsilon). \end{aligned} ⟨Sy,Sy⟩​=⟨∑Swi​,∑Swi​⟩=i∑​⟨Swi​,Swi​⟩+i​=j∑​⟨Swi​,Swj​⟩=i∑​∥wi​∥22​+i​=j∑​⟨wi​,wj​⟩±ϵi,j∑​∥wi​∥2​∥wj​∥2​=⟨∑wi​,∑wi​⟩+O(ϵ)=⟨y,y⟩±O(ϵ).​

So, we have established that a JLT for the 1/21/21/2-net over the unit sphere in the column space of AAA is an ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​-subspace embedding for the column space of AAA. We know that ∣N∣≤5d\lvert \mathcal{N} \rvert \leq 5^d∣N∣≤5d, so that k=Ω(ϵ−2log⁡(5d/δ))=Ω(ϵ−2(d+1log⁡(1/δ)))k = \Omega(\epsilon^{-2} \log (5^d/\delta)) = \Omega(\epsilon^{-2} (d + 1\log (1/\delta)))k=Ω(ϵ−2log(5d/δ))=Ω(ϵ−2(d+1log(1/δ))) as desired.
